tossups.question: The Post tag machine is a finite state machine whose only tape is one of these entities. The Intel 8086 used one of these structures to store prefetch instructions. Lindley processes can be used to describe the evolution of the length of these data structures over time. Setting an upper bound on the size of one of these entities allows a constant time implementation using a circular buffer. Kendall’s notation is used to classify and describe these data structures. This data structure is used in a (*) breadth-first search to store the vertices to be visited. Double-ended types of these data structures are called deques (“DECKS”), and one variant of these data structures stores elements by their priority. As opposed to stacks, these data structures are first-in-first-out. For 10 points, name this data structure which can represent people waiting in line.

Every time this polity conquered another, its leader ordered construction of palaces aligned with the constellations of the Royal Chamber and Heavenly Apex. X-ray fluorescence research led by University College London found that 40,000 arrowheads created by this polity were manufactured in the same batch. 46 life-sized bronze waterfowls created by this state were excavated from a riverbank-shaped structure. Skeletons excavated at Yonglu may give credence to the account of the (*) live burial of 400,000 Zhao soldiers by this state's general Bai Qi (“BY-CHEE”). Heavy metal contamination in soil near Xi'an confirms some aspects of Sima Qian's account of hundreds of mercury rivers being constructed by 700,000 laborers for this state's greatest mausoleum. For 10 points, name this state whose namesake dynasty created the Terracotta Army under Shi Huangdi.
tossups.answer: Qin Dynasty [or Qíncháo; or Qin State; or Qin Kingdom; or Qin Empire; prompt on China]
tossups.answer_formatted: Qin Dynasty [or Qíncháo; or Qin State; or Qin Kingdom; or Qin Empire; prompt on China]

tossups.question: According to legend, Archimedes invented his namesake screw while on a visit to this city after watching its river rise and fall. An inventor from this city described a valve that released holy water when a coin was released, the first vending machine, in his book Mechanics and Optics. That engineer from this city also invented the (*) first steam-powered engine, the aeolipile. The distance between this city and Syene was used to calculate the circumference of the Earth by Eratosthenes. Callimachus composed the Pinakes (“pin-AH-keez”) to catalog the contents of a building in this city, in which a Christian mob killed the mathematician Hypatia centuries later. This city’s pharos was an immense lighthouse in its harbor, and many Hellenistic scholars flocked to its Great Library. For 10 points, name this Egyptian port city of Hero, Euclid, and Ptolemy (“TALL-uh-mee”), founded by a Macedonian conqueror.

The still life artist Fede Galizia painted a version of this scene containing a possible self-portrait. The Museo di Capodimonte houses a version of this scene that provides the cover for a book by Mary Garrard. In 2016, the Louvre chose not to purchase a version of this scene found in a Toulouse attic that has been attributed to Caravaggio (“kah-rah-VAH-joh”). An artist’s depictions of Jael and Sisera and Susannah and the Elders are thematically similar to (*) her 1610 depiction of this scene. The actions of the artist’s mentor Agostino Tassi, who was hired by her father Orazio, inspired a depiction of this scene that features blood soaking a delicate white mattress and was completed a year before the artist’s rape trial. For 10 points, a maid and an Assyrian general appear in Artemisia Gentileschi’s violent depiction of what Biblical scene?
tossups.answer: Judith beheading Holofernes [accept any answer mentioning both Judith and Holofernes]
tossups.answer_formatted: Judith beheading Holofernes [accept any answer mentioning both Judith and Holofernes]
acceptable: any answer mentioning both Judith and Holofernes

tossups.question: In signal processing, the autocorrelation function of white noise is proportional to this function. In quantum mechanics, for a potential of this form, the reflection and transmission coefficients of scattering states are the same whether the potential is a barrier or a well. The bound state wavefunctions for a potential well of this type decay exponentially on either side of the well center. The Fourier transform of this function equals (*) 1, and it is the derivative of the Heaviside step function. The integral over the whole domain of the product of any other function f times this function of quantity x minus a is equal to the value of f at a, which is called this function’s sifting property. For 10 points, name this generalized function which is useful in physics because its integral is one though its value is infinite at the origin and zero everywhere else, and which is named for a British physicist.
tossups.answer: Dirac delta function [accept unit impulse function]

tossups.question: In one work, this author describes a woman’s face with the “unfair words” “white” and “bleak,” with eyes like “two puffs of green slime.” “A marshy smell” and the smell of war unusually appear in a dream in a story by this author which repeats the phrase “war of the blossom.” This author wrote a story in which two characters in a novel come to life to kill its reader and another where a motorcycle accident was actually a dream and the narrator’s sacrifice by the Aztecs is real. This author of “The (*) Night Face Up” and “The Continuity of Parks” also wrote a story in which a man obsessively watches, then becomes, the title type of salamander, and a story in which the photographer Roberto Michel enlarges a picture of a seduction. For 10 points, name this author of “Axolotl” and “Blow-Up,” who also wrote the nonlinear novel Hopscotch.

The most famous philosophical work titled after this concept quotes Wilhelm von Humboldt for its epigraph. An 1816 speech that distinguished between the way that this concept was understood by “the ancients” and the way that it was currently understood by “the moderns” was delivered to the Paris Athenaeum by Benjamin Constant. Machiavelli’s Discourses on Livy asserts that this concept existed in Rome due to the “tumults” between the “nobles and the plebs.” A work that ends with the essay (*) “Why I am not a Conservative” is titled after “The Constitution of” this concept, and was written by Friedrich Hayek. A famous essay about this idea distinguishes between its “positive” and “negative” conceptions. For 10 points, identify this idea whose “Two Concepts” were discussed in an Isaiah Berlin essay, and which titles the most famous work of John Stuart Mill.

One ballet premiered by this company is choreographed to Humphrey Searle’s orchestration of Franz Liszt’s Piano Sonata in B minor and is an adaption of La dame aux Camélias by Alexandre Dumas fils. While working for this company, one dancer developed a step that starts from an arabesque, moves through several intermediate steps, and ends with a pas de chat (“pah duh shah”). That artistic director of this company created the ballet Symphonic Variations, and choreographed Marguerite and Armand specifically for the dancing partners Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev. A decade prior to taking its current name, this company moved from its original site of (*) Sadler’s Wells to Covent Garden. Kenneth MacMillan took over as artistic director of this company following the departure of Frederick Ashton. For 10 points, name this leading British ballet company, which got its current name in 1956 after receiving a charter from the monarchy.
tossups.answer: The Royal Ballet [accept Sadler’s Wells Ballet; accept Vic-Wells Ballet before the word “Sadler’s”]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Royal Ballet [accept Sadler’s Wells Ballet; accept Vic-Wells Ballet before the word “Sadler’s”]

tossups.question: This author dedicated one of his novels “To a Happier Year” and wrote in the author’s note that “A happy ending was imperative” and that the two central characters were still roaming the greenwood. Their happy ending began when one of the characters failed to go to Buenos Aires and met the title character at a boathouse, saying “And now we shan’t be parted no more, and that’s finished.” A pivotal scene in a novel by this author occurs when the title character throws open his windows at night and shouts “Come!” which prompts the arrival of (*) Alex Scudder. Another of his novels begins with the epigraph “Only connect” and sees the death of Leonard Bast at the hands of Charles Wilcox, which prompts his father to leave the title estate to his wife Margaret Schlegel. For 10 points, name this author of Maurice and Howards End.

The Savoyard diplomat Eustace Chapuys became close with this future monarch while legally defending the aunt of Emperor Charles V. Juan Luis Vives wrote De Institutione Feminae Christianae to educate this future monarch. Cardinal Reginald Pole negotiated the revival of the Heresy Acts with this monarch on behalf of Pope Julius III. This monarch exclaimed “[when I am dead], you shall find ‘Calais’ (“kull-AY”) lying in my heart” after its conquest by Francis I. Thomas Wyatt the Younger revolted against this monarch over fears of her marriage to (*) Philip II of Spain. Ovarian cancer or fibroid tumors may have been the cause of this queen’s two phantom pregnancies. Foxe’s Book of Martyrs memorializes victims of this queen’s persecution including Thomas Cranmer. For 10 points, name this “Bloody” Catholic queen of England and sister to Elizabeth I.
tossups.answer: Mary I of England [or Bloody Mary; or Mary Tudor; prompt on Mary; do not accept “Mary, Queen of Scots”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Mary I of England [or Bloody Mary; or Mary Tudor; prompt on Mary; do not accept "“Mary, Queen of Scots”"]

tossups.question: One of this author’s narrators claims “I am the man who never got ahead.” He is asked “who are you that mumbles in the dark? And who are you that draws your veil across the stars?” and responds that he is in a place where he finds only “the same old stupid plan / Of dog eat dog.” This author yearned for a place to “be the dream the dreamers dreamed” in one work, and described being sent “to eat in the kitchen / when company comes.” This author of a poem with the line (*) “America never was America to me” described an object with “boards torn up” and a woman who was “still climbin’” even though life “ain’t been no crystal stair.” A poem beginning “I, too, sing America,” and “Mother to Son” were written by this poet. For 10 points, name this Harlem Renaissance poet who wrote “Dream Deferred” and “The Negro Speaks of Rivers.”
tossups.answer: Langston Hughes [or James Mercer Langston Hughes]

tossups.question: Worship of this deity involved aischrologia (“ICE-crow-LOW-gee-uh”), derisive lewd jokes meant to imitate a servant of this deity. While disguised as a mortal, this deity was invited by a group of sisters led by Kallithoê (“CAL-ih-THO-eh”) to work for their mother. Plants that were thought to be aphrodisiacs were used to make seats for women who fasted at a festival to honor this deity. This deity was entertained by a maid who told lewd jokes and showed this deity her (*) vagina; that maid was either Iambe (“eye-AM-bee”) or Baubo. This deity mourning the loss of a relative was remembered at the Thesmophoria festival. Triptolemus (TRIP-TALL-Uh-Muss) was taught the secrets of a festival of this deity which began shortly after she attempted to make the baby Demophoon (“DEH-mo-FOE-on”) immortal by placing him in a fire. Dionysus was honored at an initiation cult of this goddess and her daughter. Hades abducted the daughter of, for 10 points, what goddess of agriculture and mother of Persephone?

This politician first articulated the delinking of the ESDI, duplicating existing efforts, and discriminating against non-EU members as the “three Ds” that NATO must avoid. As Ambassador to the UN, this politician led a veto war in “Operation Orient Express” to deny Boutros Boutros-Ghali a second term. In response to a query about half a million dead children, this diplomat defended sanctions against Iraq with the line (*) “we think the price is worth it.” This successor to Warren Christopher converted to Catholicism in her childhood for safety from the Nazis while her father worked in the cabinet of Edvard Beneš (“BEH-nesh”). Vaclav Havel urged this author of the memoir Madam Secretary to run for election as his successor. For 10 points, name this Czech-born Secretary of State under Bill Clinton, the first woman to hold the office.

A derivative of this compound is added to anthranilate (“AN-thruh-NILE-ate”) during the biosynthesis of tryptophan. It’s not phosphate, but each repeating unit of the polymer created by PARP (“parp”) contains two equivalents of this compound. A derivative of this compound with a pyrophosphate and a phosphate group is added to nucleosides in the first step of the purine salvage pathway by either HGPRT or APRT, and its 5-phosphate is formed by its namesake isomerase in the first non-oxidative step of the (*) pentose phosphate pathway. The fact that this compound has a two-prime hydroxyl group allows for polymers containing this sugar to form tertiary structure and to self-splice in some instances. For 10 points, name this pentose sugar found in the backbone of RNA and that differs by one OH group from the sugar found in DNA.

Gayle Sherwood Magee’s biography [this composer] Reconsidered responds to Maynard Solomon’s claim that this composer backdated his pieces. The first complete catalogue of this composer’s works was assembled by James Sinclair. This composer’s fourth symphony includes a part for an “ether organ.” A piano piece by him includes optional parts for flute and viola and quotes the four-note fate motif from Beethoven’s fifth symphony in (*) each movement. That sonata instructs the performer to depress the keys with a long piece of wood in the second movement, which is titled “Hawthorne.” Another piece by this composer depicts a monument sculpted by Augustus St. Gaudens in its first movement, and the Housatonic River in its third movement. For 10 points, name this American composer of the Concord Sonata and Three Places in New England.

The chief minister of one kingdom of these people would signal that a disfavored king must commit suicide by presenting him a parrot’s egg. Sungbo’s Eredo is a defensive system of walls and ditches built to commemorate a female ruler of this people’s Ijebu kingdom. Nobles in Ogboni lodges and councilors in the Mesi advised the Alaafin of these people’s Oyo Kingdom, whose powerful cavalry enabled them to subjugate the neighboring (*) Dahomey Kingdom. Priests of these people use a chain or nut in the Ifa practice of divination, which was consulted during the royal succession of oba chiefs. These people trace their origins to the holy city of Ile-Ife (“EE-lay-EE-fay”), which was legendarily founded by the orisha Oduduwa. For 10 points, name this ethnic group that, along with the Hausa-Fulani and Igbo, dominates Nigeria.

The extent of this phenomenon is encoded by the weighted average negative sigma and weighted average positive sigma. This phenomenon is used to explain why halide groups are ortho/para directing despite being electron-withdrawing. This phenomenon is used to explain why methanol is a weaker acid than phenol. Major and minor contributors in this process are distinguished by their (*) stability. Like hyperconjugation, this phenomenon stabilizes both carbocations and free radicals. This phenomenon leads to a partial charge of negative one-half on each oxygen of a carboxylic acid. Double-headed arrows are used to display interchange between different Lewis structures in molecules undergoing this phenomenon. For 10 points, name this phenomenon in which electrons are delocalized
tossups.answer: resonance [or electron delocalization before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on “aromaticity” or “hyperconjugation”]
tossups.answer_formatted: resonance [or electron delocalization before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "“aromaticity”" or "“hyperconjugation”"]

tossups.question: These people are surrounded with jewelry on a silver platter meant to contrast the rituals involved with the golden calf as part of a celebration described in Exodus 13. Any leavened bread is burned on the morning of the 14th of Nisan in honor of these people. In Exodus 19, God gives the function of the priesthood to the Levites after taking it away from these people known as (*) bekhor. Five shekels are offered to the rabbi on pidyon haben (“PEED-yon hah-BEN”) for the redemption of these people. These people’s namesake fast celebrates an event in which lamb’s blood was spread on Israelites’ doors to protect these people. Passover celebrates, for 10 points, the survival of what people who enjoy a greater inheritance and birthright?
tossups.answer: firstborn sons [prompt on sons; prompt on children]

tossups.question: One character on this show quotes “We must not look at goblin men / We must not buy their fruits” after the bus passenger Sky begins repeating everyone’s words. One man on this show climbs through the window of the Coal Hill School to correct a teacher about Pride and Prejudice. This show’s episode “World Enough and Time” refers to the possible reforming of the (*) Mistress. Another character on this show quotes Oscar Wilde by saying she needs something sensational to read on a spaceship, so she always carries her blue diary; that character is River Song. This show’s title character takes Martha Jones to visit Shakespeare and Rose Tyler to visit Dickens. Jodie Whittaker plays the first female regeneration of this show’s Gallifreyan title character. For 10 points, name this show whose time-traveling title character visits various literary figures using the TARDIS.

One section of a book named for this character advises the reader to just skip the next pages before telling a landlord’s smutty story about a youth and a king who end up sleeping with the same woman. One book about this character ends with the narrator explaining he couldn’t finish the book because Italy has just been invaded by the French. Ruggerio marries the female (*) knight Bradamante in a book in which this man kills King Agramante. This man duels his cousin Rinaldo for a woman who ends up leaving him for a Saracen, causing him to fly to the Valley of Lost Things on the Moon to retrieve his sanity in a bottle. In a Boiardo romance named after this character “Innamorato,” he falls in love with the Chinese princess Angelica. For 10 points, name this paladin of Charlemagne, who, in an epic poem by Ariosto, is “Furioso.”

bonuses.leadin: When conducting research, it’s important that your glassware and equipment are clean. Answer the following about cleaning things in the lab. For 10 points each:
parts: This method is commonly carried out in low-pressure argon or oxygen; organic residue may be broken down by reactive oxygen species and short-wave UV radiation emitted in this technique.
Sterilizing growth media, surgical equipment or some biohazardous waste often requires use of this high-pressure device. Another version of this device may be used to convert gels to aerogels.
This chemical is often used in the lab for easy cleaning and fast drying of glassware, although this simplest ketone is also the basis for many nail polish removers.

bonuses.leadin: A 2012 study in the American Journal of Sociology found that in Milwaukee, 30% of the people to whom this process occurs are black women, even though they comprise only 9% of the population. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process, which may be initiated by a landlord, in which families are expelled from their rented homes. So-called "informal" types of this process may include paying off tenants to move.
This Princeton sociologist's book Evicted won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize for his study of eight families in Milwaukee trying to find housing.

Desmond’s Evicted is an example of this type of method, in which the researcher is immersed in the daily lives of the target population in an attempt to document them. It involves documenting the results of participant observation and fieldwork.

bonuses.leadin: Towards the end of this novel, its earlier sections are revealed to have been written by its main character in an attempt to make amends for what she did when she was younger. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel, in which Briony Tallis misconstrues the relationship between her sister Cecilia and Robbie Turner and later gets Robbie sent to prison by accusing him of raping her cousin Lola.
This British author of Amsterdam and Saturday is better known for creating Briony and Cecilia Tallis in Atonement.
In Atonement, after Robbie accidentally sends Cecilia a private draft of an explicit love letter, the two of them notably have sex in one of these places.

bonuses.leadin: As a result of this battle, Braxton Bragg resigned his command and was reassigned as military advisor to Jefferson Davis. For 10 points each:
answers: MacArthur [or Arthur MacArthur; or Douglas Macarthur]
parts: Name this Tennessee battle where Union troops under Virginian George Henry Thomas stormed the rifle pits up the namesake geographical feature. This battle resulted in the lifting of the Confederate siege of Chattanooga.

One man with this surname won the Medal of Honor for planting his regimental colors on Missionary Ridge with the cry “On Wisconsin!” George Marshall gave his son of this surname the same award after he and his staff evacuated from Corregidor Island on four PT boats.

After Missionary Ridge, Abraham Lincoln promoted this commanding officer at the battle to Lieutenant General, a rank previously reserved for George Washington. This general succeeded Andrew Johnson as President.

bonuses.leadin: Some of these instruments have a detachable upper tumba that helps balance the weight and add resonance. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this stringed instrument of the lute family native to the Indian subcontinent. It was played by Ravi Shankar.

The sympathetic strings of the sitar are tuned to these melodic patterns which form the basis of improvisation in Hindustani music. They are analogous to scales and modes, and the behavior of their notes is called chalan.

While Hindustani music featuring the sitar was heavily influenced by contact with Persia, this style of southern Indian music remained more voice-oriented. Kriti form the core repertoire of this tradition, which is characterized by complex rhythms or tala.

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. In 2014, Wissam Akiki created controversy by becoming the first person in the Americas with this distinction. For 10 points each:
answers: married priests [accept reasonable descriptions; accept clergy in place of priests]
parts: Identify this distinction commonly given in Latin as “viri probati.” The synod in the Amazon will be held in October 2019 to discuss this distinction.
This Protestant reformed set a precedent for clerical marriage by marrying Katharina von Bora. He is better known for nailing his 95 theses to the door of the All Saints’ Church in Wittenburg.
The aforementioned Wissam Akiki is a member of the clergy of this oldest Eastern Catholic church, based in Bkerke (“ib-KER-key”), Lebanon.
answers_formatted: married priests [accept reasonable descriptions; accept clergy in place of priests]

bonuses.leadin: In polar coordinates, these curves may be given by the general formula “r equals the semi-latus rectum over quantity one plus cosine theta times eccentricity.” For 10 points each:
answers: conic sections [or conics, prompt on answers mentioning cones]
parts: Name this category of curves, including ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas, that can be obtained from the intersection of a plane with a certain three-dimensional shape.

Conic sections were studied by this Greek mathematician, who also names a theorem stating that the sum of the square of two sides of a triangle equals the square of the length of the median dividing the third side plus the square of half the length of the third side.
For any point on a conic section, the conic’s eccentricity is equal to the ratio of the point’s distance to a focus and its distance to this line.
answers_formatted: conic sections [or conics, prompt on answers mentioning cones]
acceptable: conics, prompt on answers mentioning cones

bonuses.leadin: Napoleon proclaimed Marshal Auguste de Marmont as “Duke of [this place]” after he annexed it to the Kingdom of Italy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this merchant republic centered at the port of Dubrovnik in modern-day Croatia.

Ragusa fell under the domination of this other Adriatic merchant republic during the Fourth Crusade. Besides invading Ragusa, this republic’s doge Enrico Dandolo used the crusaders to sack the Byzantine capital.
After a Russo-Ottoman fleet captured this formerly-Venetian island group from France in 1799, they established oligarchic Septinsular Republic based on the model of Ragusa.

bonuses.leadin: One of these objects asks "fill me with the old familiar juice, / Methinks I might recover by and by." For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects, which have a dialogue asking "did the hand then of [their maker] shake?" before "one of the loquacious Lot" asks who they are and who is their maker.
Name this poem which features the metaphor of the pots. It also claims that "The Bird of Time...is on the wing" and describes an object which "having writ, moves on."
This polymath poet asked for only "a jug of wine, a loaf of bread, and thou" in the Rubaiyat.

bonuses.leadin: This politician was once reportedly trapped on a campaign bus by protestors armed with milkshakes. For 10 points each:
answers: National Rally [or Rassemblement national; accept NR or RN]
parts: Name this British politician, one of the major supporters of the 'Leave' campaign. A founding member of UKIP, he now leads the Brexit Party.
Farage and UKIP have been identified as part of a growing right-wing populist trend in Europe, along with this French party once called the National Front. This party is led by Marine Le Pen.

The popularity of European populist parties may correlate with this attitude, whose adherents include Henri Joyeux and Andrew Wakefield. In August 2019, the UK government announced plans to convene a summit of social media companies to address this attitude.

bonuses.leadin: A seemingly psychic man witnesses and copes with the aftermath of a deadly automobile accident in one short story titled for this action. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this action, which is undertaken by an unnamed narrator of a Denis Johnson short story in the collection Jesus’ Son. He consumes drugs and alcohol given to him by strangers he meets while performing this action.
In this novel, Kilgore Trout hitchhikes to Midland City, where he meets Dwayne Hoover, who, after reading Trout’s writing, believes that he is the only person in the universe with free will.
Jack Kerouac included his experiences with hitchhiking in this novel, in which Sal Paradise and Dean Moriarty travel across America and meet other fictionalized figures from the Beat movement.

bonuses.leadin: Susano’o scared this deity by throwing a flayed horse at her loom, causing her to hide in a cave. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sun deity who only emerged from her cave after Ame-no-Uzume performed a lewd dance for her. That dance inspired the kagura often performed in Japanese theater.

These people performed the sanghyang dance to depict the struggle between Barong and the demon Rangda, who was conflated with Durga. These people believe that the world serpent Antaboga created the world turtle Bedwang.
The aforementioned sanghyang dance somewhat resembles the Chinese lion dance, inspired by the monster Nian, who was chased away by objects with this color.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about spectral lines of atoms. For 10 points each:
parts: Atomic spectral lines can be split by an electric field in this effect. This effect is the electrical counterpart of the Zeeman effect.
Howard Moseley developed an expression for the spectral emission lines of atoms in this part of the spectrum. That expression only depends on quantity atomic number minus one squared.

In general, calculating the spectra of multi-electron atoms is challenging because this quantum mechanical equation becomes impossible to solve exactly. Its time-independent form is written “H-psi equals E-psi.”

bonuses.leadin: A crucifix hung in this province’s National Assembly until it passed a 2019 ban on public sector workers wearing religious symbols. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Canadian province, whose premier Jacques Parizeau blamed the ‘No’ vote of a 1995 sovereignty referendum on “money and the ethnic vote.”
Charles de Gaulle appeared in Montreal at this mid-century event and declared “Vive le Québec libre!”
Expo 67 occurred in the midst of this socializing, secularizing revolution, which followed the “The Great Darkness” of Maurice Duplessis’ (“DOO-pless-ee’s”) time as premier of Quebec.

bonuses.leadin: This composer wrote a solo for the posthorn in the second menuet of his Serenade in D, K.320. For 10 points each:
answers: basset-horn [do not accept or prompt on “horn” alone]
Prague [or Praha] (That composer is Bedřich Smetana.)
parts: Name this composer, whose other serenades include Eine kleine Nachtmusik for string ensemble.

Mozart called for three of these obscure woodwinds in his Masonic Funeral Music and two in his Serenade in B-flat, K. 361. Despite its name, this instrument is a member of the clarinet family, with a range that extends about a fifth lower than a standard clarinet.

Mozart’s clarinet concerto, originally planned for basset-horn, was premiered in this city. Mozart's Symphony No. 38 is nicknamed for this city, and a later composer depicted a castle here in the tone poem Vyšehrad (“vi-SHE-he-rad”).
answers_formatted: basset-horn [do not accept or prompt on "“horn” alone"]

bonuses.leadin: This biologist once remarked that if God exists, he has an “inordinate fondness for beetles.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this father of population genetics. This biologist’s namesake “dilemma” claims that selection cost for positive traits is insufficient in explaining high mutation rates observed in species.
Haldane’s dilemma was resolved by Motoo Kimura, who hypothesized that most mutations generated by genetic drift are functionally in this state where they are neither beneficial nor detrimental.

The neutral theory predicts that the diversity within a species is directly proportional to this quantity. For humans, this value is currently just above seven billion, and the carrying capacity is the maximum of this value.

bonuses.leadin: This post-Marxist Belgian philosopher has argued that there is “no beyond hegemony.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this thinker who co-authored Hegemony and Socialist Strategy with Ernesto Laclau. She criticized “third way” liberal politics in The Democratic Paradox.
Mouffe draws strongly from this Italian Marxist, who first theorized the concept of hegemony in his Prison Notebooks.
The third part of the Prison Notebooks is dedicated to the philosophy of this concept. Gramsci loosely defined this concept as a conscious activity that aims at a political goal.

bonuses.leadin: The goal of this author’s style of writing was to use as many words to convey as little meaning as possible, which resulted in phrases like “the half moon arms of his forehead” that describe a bull’s horns. For 10 points each:
answers: Spanish Golden Age [or Siglo de Oro]
parts: Name this rival of the poet Francisco de Quevedo whose culteranismo style opposed Quevedo’s conceptismo.
Góngora and Quevedo were both members of this period of flourishing of Spanish arts and literature.

This author was a member of the “Generation of ‘27,” formed to commemorate the 300th anniversary of Gongora’s death. He wrote poems like “Death of a Bullfighter” before being executed in the Spanish Civil War.

bonuses.leadin: This ruler assumed the throne on the same night as the birth of his son Al-Ma’mun (“ULL MUH-   -moon”), the “Night of the Three Caliphs.” For 10 points each:
answers: Barmakids [or Barmecides; or Barmakīyān; or al-Barāmikah]
parts: Name this Abbasid caliph whose personal library became Baghdad’s House of Wisdom under the patronage of his successors. This caliph famously gifted an elephant and a water clock to Charlemagne.
Harun Al-Rashid appears frequently in One Thousand and One Nights with his vizier Ja’far, who hailed from this influential Persian family.

The Barmakids traced back to the hereditary pramukh administrators of Nava Vihara, a monastery of this religion in Balkh. Xuanzang, a Chinese monk of this religion, described Nava Vihara in his account of his travels.

bonuses.leadin: A closeup of one of these paintings by this artist that is titled The Wounded Man provides the cover for Linda Nochlin’s monograph on their artist. For 10 points each:
answers: self-portraits of Gustave Courbet [prompt on partial answers]
A Burial At Ornans [or Un enterrement à Ornans; or A Funeral At Ornans]
parts: Name both the genre of paintings and their artist. One of these works by this artist prominently features a cello, while another shows the wide eyed central figure pulling his hair back in anxiety and is titled The Desperate Man.
For the 1850 Salon, Gustave Courbet used the gigantic scale of history painting for this painting that depicts a funeral for his great-uncle in his hometown.

While not posing for his friend Courbet’s The Artist’s Studio, this poet and art critic savaged the mechanical nature of photography and defined the modern artist as a spectator in The Painter of Modern Life.
answers_formatted: A Burial At Ornans [or Un enterrement à Ornans; or A Funeral At Ornans]
